dataset.title: Marine bird and mammal observations in the North Pacific Ocean, 2002-2006

associatedParty.organizationName: The National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis (NCEAS)

abstract.para: This data provides observation of marine birds and mammals along a 7,500 km east-west CPR transect. Data were collected aboard a platform of opportunity (M/V Skaubryn). Due to the large size of the M/V Skaubryn, modifications were made to the standardized marine bird survey techniques (Tasker et al. 1984, Buckland et al. 1993). Species-specific detection and identification curves revealed that the optimal strip-width for this vessel was 400m (Hyrenbach et al., submitted). Marine mammals were recorded using line transect techniques; sightings from the centerline to the horizon were recorded, and the radial distance and the angle from the track were estimated (Heinemann 1981, Buckland et al. 1993).

keywordSet.keyword: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council

intellectualRights.para:
This material is based upon work supported by the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed herein are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views or positions of the Trustee Council.
Acknowledgment to be used in any reports/publications (but please check prior to final publication for amendments):
"Pacific CPR data collection is supported by a consortium for the North Pacific CPR survey coordinated by the North Pacific Marine Science Organisation (PICES) and comprising the North Pacific Research Board (NPRB), Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council (EVOS TC), Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans (DFO) and the Sir Alister Hardy Foundation for Ocean Science (SAHFOS)."
Standard scientific norms for attribution and credit to funding agencies should be followed when using these data. Please send a copy of any publications/reports arising from the use of Pacific CPR data to Sonia Batten soba@sahfos.ac.uk

section.title: Marine Bird and Mammal Observations
section.para: Data are collected along an at-sea transect beginning in British Columbia, Canada and ending in Honshu, Japan. Because the vessel is a platform of opportunity (i.e. a cargo ship) the cruise track varies from survey to survey. However, most cruise tracks pass through the Gulf of Alaska, Bering Sea, and the Western Subarctic Gyre.

Data records represent daily bins of survey data derived from continuous transect data (i.e. each record represents the summed counts and transect areas for a given calendar day during a survey). Bins were created using software designed for this purpose. Marine birds and mammals exhibiting ship-attracted behaviors are not included in this dataset (bow-riding mammals were considered to be ship-attracted). Counts included in this dataset represent the summed totals of all observed behaviors exhibited by the marine birds and mammals

Starting/ending latitude and longitude coordinates represent where each date's survey began/ended. There is not, however, continuous survey coverage between these start and end coordinates. The average latitude and longitude coordinates therefore correspond to the mean of the transect lengths surveyed. Latitude and longitude coordinates are manually entered by the observer and cruise tracks were verified in a GIS post-survey.
The same observer has collected all of the data contained in this dataset, eliminating between-observer bias.

project.title: A CPR-Based Plankton Survey Using Ships of Opportunity to Monitor the GOA

funding.para: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council project number 02624, 030624, 040624, 070624, 10100624, 12120114A, 13120114A; North Pacific Research Board (NPRB); Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans (DFO); Sir Alister Hardy Foundation for Ocean Science (SAHFOS)
